body: There was a steady stream of alpha releases in the first half of last year, but the last alpha was ~7 months ago. I realize the difficulty of pulling off such an ambitious refactor, yet still wanted to respectfully ask what the current status / roadmap / plan is.

comment_data.body: Cython is run by a very small set of unpaid developers, with a high variance in the amount of time they are able to put in. 3.0 is still something we'd like to do, but it's not something we can assign a timeline to.

I am very interested in Cython 3's roadmap/plan too, and I suppose it does not necessarily need to be tied to a committed timeline ðŸ™‚ At least to me getting to know what's ahead of us with Cython 3 is enough. A more interesting question is the roadmap (again, no timeline needed) for Cython 0.29.x *after* Cython 3.0 is out (would it be deprecated/unsupported/etc).

I think version 3 development has come a long way https://github.com/cython/cython/milestone/58 , maybe after another alpha release, it will be easier to find out other blockers and figure out a possible rough timeline. also, more requent contribuotrs could be added as collaborator & fundraising could be run.
I'll try to get a new release out during the next days, to get things rolling again.

For those subscribed to this issue: 3.0.0alpha7 has been released ðŸ¥³ 

Thanks @scoder & everyone who helped!

Not sure if this is worth a separate issue, but wanted to ask if the final version is supposed to be `3.0` (since the alphas are called `3.0a7` etc.) or `3.0.0`?

Currently it's a three-part number (`0.29.23`), and I think it should stay that way. Presumably the project will use SemVer? If not, the intended version scheme should be noted somewhere (though, realistically, people end up expecting SemVer anyway, even when it's explicitly documented not to be, as the recent experience with `cryptography` showed...).

If it's going to be `3.0.0`, the naming of the (to-be-released) alphas should reflect that...

Good call @h-vetinari. We'll definitely continue to use three parts. It should be `3.0.0` then, although both would be [PEP-440](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/) compliant.

It's probably not strictly SemVer that we use, just like it's probably not strictly SemVer that any other project in the world uses. But increasing minor and micro versions should, on average, get better and not worse. ;-)

I'm sorry to be "that person"... I'm just wondering if it's not worth to release all the already existing improvements in 3.0.0 sooner rather than later. I remember a time (e.g. [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2800#issuecomment-466781420)) when 3.0 had been planned to be released in 2019, which is not in any way meant as a criticism - I get how ambitious this project is, and how constrained the resources.

Still, version numbers are cheap (perhaps aside from the emotional attachment) - why not release 3.0 more or less as is, and push the blockers to 4.0? There are many improvements in the master branch that people are waiting for (or even blocked on). This would also finally open the door for removing py27, py34 & py35 support (for reference, even py36 is EOL in 3 month)...

I ask mainly because the todo-list for 3.0 has not gotten substantially shorter in recent times, and there doesn't seem to be a plan-of-attack to tackle it (which is fine!). But perhaps perfect is the enemy of good here, and pushing out a new major version could relieve some pressure and rejuvinate spirits. ðŸ™ƒ

> version numbers are cheap

The counter argument is that there is a perfectly serviceable alpha version available so anyone interested can experience the future, now ;)

-----------

I think the main aim for 3.0 was to try to get any changes likely to break user code over in one go. I'm not sure how many of those there actually are remaining - possibly the switch to `language_level=3` and `binding=True` were the main ones. But one option would be to prioritise only those changes.

> perfectly serviceable alpha version

I think the vast majority of downstream projects will not adopt anything but a full release. They might be testing with 3.0.0a, but they won't ever switch to depending on an alpha version. Which is one of my main points, because there's a lot of good stuff in the repo that's 3.0.0a-only at the moment.

Agree. No release, no switch over. It's been like this for the vast majority of projects that I know/participate. Moreover, staying in alpha would not help distro people get prepared either. The middle ground to me is to make at least an rc release.
one of the coolest things from 3.0 is the volatile keyword. other than installing the version from GitHub, it seems hard to use that feature.

@h-vetinari, I think you're right. Most of the truly critical 3.0 issues are solved. What remains with regard to incompatible changes is:
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4280
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2304

[The rest](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22P%3A+blocker%22) are mostly bugs, which by definition aren't release critical (enough to block the 3.0 release).

~Both tickets above have PRs~
The first is easy to implement, the second has a PR, just not ready yet. I think that can be worked on. Then we should be close.

> Both tickets above have PRs

I can't see a PR for #4280? (Although I guess the actually change would be pretty small and the work would be in the tests)

--------

@hmaarrfk 

> other than installing the version from GitHub, it seems hard to use that feature.

`pip install Cython==3.0.0a9`

> I can't see a PR for #4280?

Sorry, I mixed it up with another ticket. #4280 is easy to implement but has a potentially large impact on user code.

Cool, i didn't know we could install alphase from pip that way. It does complicate my (conda) based environment, but maybe worth the risk.

Personally, I think that the alpha cython requirement puts me on the "too complicated" for "a half step toward pure-C implementation". But thank you for the tip.

(I might be tempted to make a conda package for myself maybe :/)

> I might be tempted to make a conda package for myself maybe

I have a PR for conda-forge open: https://github.com/conda-forge/cython-feedstock/pull/75
The only reason it is failing is because I'm now running the full test suite, rather than just some smoke tests. There are only a handful of failures, but I'm sure it would be fine to publish those to an RC branch in the cython-feedstock. We can discuss this on the PR if you're interested.

> @scoder: @h-vetinari, I think you're right. Most of the truly critical 3.0 issues are solved.

That's very great news!

> #4280 is easy to implement but has a potentially large impact on user code.

I think it would be fine to have some more pre-releases, but having such a "path" to 3.0.0 already is a big step forward! :)

> @scoder [Oct 6th, 2021]: Most of the truly critical 3.0 issues are solved. What remains with regard to incompatible changes is: #4280 #2304
> 
> [The rest](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22P%3A+blocker%22) are mostly bugs, which by definition aren't release critical (enough to block the 3.0 release).

#2304 has been solved and #4280 has a [PR](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4670) that's been languishing for a while - if that's the last real blocker, wouldn't it make sense to prioritize finishing this above most other feature/bugfix work? Not least because the backport of `noexcept` to 0.29 would probably need some time to percolate as well?

This would allow to do beta/rc/release of 3.0.0 over the course of the following months, and then finally permit the cython devs (& contributors) to save/recoup the time necessary for all the continual sync- & backport work that's needed for 0.29 until then.

> Not least because the backport of noexcept to 0.29 would probably need some time to percolate as well?

I'll see if I can get the backport of `noexcept` done. That should be fairly easily (it's largely just copy-pasting a small bit of the PR) and I think can be done in advance of the 3.0 changes
The most critical change for this alpha was https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4606. Now that that's in, I'm mostly looking through PRs that are ready to be included, then it's time for 3.0a11.

> Now that that's in, I'm mostly looking through PRs that are ready to be included, then it's time for 3.0a11.

Great to hear!

(note I wasn't really talking about the content of the next alpha here, more about 3.0.0 overall)

3.0.0a11 is released. I could live with starting the beta release phase now.

Since this was the first 3.0 release to support the upcoming Py3.11, I postponed a couple of waiting PRs in order to reduce the risk of breakage for those who want to test their code with that. I'll see that I get them merged during the next days, wait a bit for feedback on this release, and then it's probably time to move on into beta.

If you have a PR hanging around that you think is ready to be included, please add a comment there to nominate it for the beta release, referring back to this issue so that they show up here.

Are all of those https://github.com/cython/cython/milestone/58 should be merged / implemented or will some be moved to 3.1?
It's just that some of those require new features.

> Are all of those https://github.com/cython/cython/milestone/58 should be merged / implemented or will some be moved to 3.1? It's just that some of those require new features.

I suspect at least some of them will be left for later.
Is there anything except https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4280 that is still needed for a final Cython 3 release?

Probably all of the blockers from 3.0 milestones, e.g. #2912, #1274, #1434, #2079, #3651, #4193, #4280, #4936, here's a [list](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22P%3A+blocker%22)

> Probably all of the blockers from 3.0 milestones [...]

@scoder [mentioned](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4022#issuecomment-936963181) quite a while ago that the only _real_ blockers for 3.0 (notwithstanding the labels) are:
* https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2304 (solved by now)
* https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4280 ([PR](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4670) in pretty advanced state)

> @scoder [Oct 6th, 2021]: @h-vetinari, I think you're right. Most of the truly critical 3.0 issues are solved. What remains with regard to incompatible changes is: #4280 #2304
> 
> [The rest](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22P%3A+blocker%22) are mostly bugs, which by definition aren't release critical (enough to block the 3.0 release).

@scoder, now that these two have been solved, what "truly critical 3.0 issues" are left, if any? I'm guessing #4936 might qualify (which has a pretty advanced [PR](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5016), luckily), is there anything else IYO?

milestone.description:
Goals:
â€“ New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
â€“ Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
â€“ Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
â€“ Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: 3.0.0 roadmap?
